awd_abstract_narration:
This project will support the participation of junior researchers (students, postdocs, and early-career faculty members) in the Nuclei and Mesoscopic Physics (NMP20) conference that will be held at the Michigan State University on May 4-8, 2020. NMP20 is the sixth conference in this series. The NMP20 conference provides a forum for theoretical and experimental physicists working at the interface of nuclear physics, condensed matter, cold temperature physics, and quantum computing, to discuss topics of current interests at the forefront of scientific research in those areas. The interactions fostered by this conference will lead to cross-disciplinary collaborations as well as new ideas that will provide new understating of nuclear structure and nuclear astrophysics problems relevant to the scientific program at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) and future Facility for Rare isotope Beams (FRIB).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Sixth Conference on Nuclei and Mesoscopic Physics, NMP'22 was held at the Michigan State University (MSU), Facility of Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB) on May 23-27, 2022. This was the sixth meeting of this series held every 2-3 years.

The NMP'22 was planned to be NMP'20 and announced in this way, then rescheduled because of pandemic in two steps, first to 2021 and then to 2022. The whole conference was organized in-person without zoom presentations.

This conference traditionally consists of relatively long presentations in the style of seminars, 45 min - 1 hour with sufficient time for questions, answers, and discussions. The participants also took part in the tour over just opened first-class DOE accelerator facility FRIB.

The mesoscopic physics is currently one of extremely fast developing branches of science and technical applications, Being, as it is clear from the term "mesoscopic", some intermediate branch between macroscopic and microscopic physics, it has to deal with small systems of particles revealing nevertheless the collective properties. It covers atoms, molecules (including biological ones), multiple artificial small man-made devices on micro- and nano-scale, and future quantum computers. Atomic nuclei present a very important example of a mesoscopic system with strong interaction between its elements. The goal of this cycle of meetings is to combine efforts of researchers working in various specific areas and discuss common problems, achievements, and new ideas.

The previous meetings of this series have demonstrated the usefulness of such open discussions. The last conference was not an exception. It is sufficient to mention just few presentations starting lively and very useful discussions. Irinel Chiorescu from the Magnetic Lab in Tallahassee discussed quantum magnets and their quantum phase diagrams. Very well known physicist from University of Manchester (United Kingdom) Raymond Bishop explained a unified microscopic theoretical approach to the many-body problem. Roman Sen'kov from La Guardia College in New York discussed a process of clusterization in nuclei. Juile Butler, at that time a graduate student at MSU/FRIB, gave a great talk about predictions of energies in many-body systems. Several presentations discussed effects of quantum chaos emerging in the systems  of interacting constituents. Special talks were devoted to quantum computers, where chaotic effects are to be carefully avoided.

Three special prizes were given for the best talks by students. The awardees were Daniel Volya from University of Florida, and two MSU graduate students, Nathan Jansen from MSU Department of Chemistry and Pierre Nzabahiman from MSU/FRIB.

The general opinion of participants was that this conference has its own style giving real chances for deep discussions and forming new collaborations; the tradition has to be continued.
